Award.AwardTitle: Cloud Droplet Evolution and Thermal Radiation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Water in the atmosphere plays a crucial role in Earth's radiation budget in all three phases. Water vapor is Earth's primary greenhouse gas; clouds play a major role in Earth's radiative energy balance. Yet there remain significant uncertainties in the understanding of water's radiative roles in the atmosphere. This uncertainty shows up prominently in cloud-radiation interactions. Some researchers have suggested there are significant missing pieces of fundamental physics regarding clouds and thermal radiation. The need to understand better the effect of increasing amounts of water in the atmosphere and the implications of missing pieces of cloud-radiation physics are the primary motivations for this project.

The objective of this project is to establish a better understanding of the role of thermal radiation in warm cloud droplet evolution: stability, evaporation, and condensation growth. Lab measurements will focus on radiation-augmented cloud droplet condensation growth and evaporation. Two separate, complementary laboratory devices are planned: a steady, isobaric flow process with radiative cooling/condensation and an unsteady, batch process with adiabatic expansion cooling followed by radiative heating/evaporation. Theoretical development and validation will be done for both droplet radiative properties and radiation-augmented mass transfer to obtain mathematical models for interpreting lab data and for microphysical and larger scale cloud simulations. Both measurements and modeling will be used to provide validation for and better understanding of the role of thermal radiation in cloud droplet evolution.

Intellectual Merit:
This study has intellectual merits at levels ranging from fundamental, scientifically oriented to product oriented. New knowledge will be generated about radiative- and phase-transitions for the most important thermal regulating substance on the planet. The findings will impact fundamental questions in cloud physics and atmospheric radiation: uncertain cloud albedos, uncertain aerosol properties, "anomalous" shortwave radiation absorption, anomalous longwave emission, water-vapor continuum absorption and emission, and the problem of cloud droplet stability in radiative and thermodynamic environments that are constantly changing. Remote sensing products and data retrieval will be impacted if this project can exploit spectral changes in condensing IR emission induced by phase-transition radiation to sense the onset of drizzle earlier and more reliably.

Broader Impacts:
This study will also have broader impacts, ranging from individuals to society at-large.
At the individual level this study will most immediately affect the education and career of a PhD graduate student whose aspirations are to become a professor and as part of his graduate training wants to return to his HBCU masters-degree institution and make presentations on research findings and experience in graduate school. Locally, workshops will be conducted for K-12 students on water properties, phase-change heat transfer, and global climate change in which inexpensive atmospheric radiation and cloud-formation monitors will be built and tested. This study will also have a broader educational impact by being incorporated into the graduate curriculum at the University of Illinois as a design project.

At a larger, societal level this study will also have far-reaching impact. The radiative phase-transition findings obtained herein will allow a better fundamental understanding of cloud microphysics and may open a door to improved global climate understanding as well as numerical weather prediction. By exploring the connections between "anomalous" infrared water radiation, the water-vapor continuum, and vapor-condensed phase transition, this study is potentially transformative in changing the way atmospheric radiation is modeled. The ultimate broad impact of this project will be a more informed society with a more accurate understanding of the fundamental thermophysical properties of Earth's primary thermal regulating fluid and principal greenhouse substance: water.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

As the current global imbalance between incoming shortwave solar radiation and outgoing longwave terrestrial-atmospheric radiation continues to warm our planet, and as the amount of water in the warming atmosphere continues to increase, understanding the meteorological and climatological roles played by water vapor, clouds, and all of water’s phase changes will continue to become even more crucial. Present uncertainties in simulating and predicting cloud droplet behavior, gaps in understanding about the interactions between cloud droplets and radiation—both incoming solar and outgoing infrared—will become even more urgent to solve. Phase changes of water—evaporation, condensation, and freezing—are the thermal engines that drive tornadoes, super-cell thunderstorms, hurricanes and other severe weather; but understanding these phase-change processes under the influence of radiation is one area of geo-science with insufficient understanding at present. The need to be able to simulate computationally the phase changes of atmospheric water and more accurately forecast ever-increasing occurrences of severe meteorological phenomena as well as predict long-term climate change will continue to become even more urgent. One particular area of cloud microphysics needing better understanding and more research is the effect of longwave infrared radiative cooling on cloud droplet evolution, primarily droplet growth by condensation of water vapor, but also cooling and freezing. 

 To this end, a combined laboratory and analytical/theoretical study was undertaken. A laboratory experiment was designed and constructed in which cloud droplets were exposed to radiative cooling, similar to what can happen at the tops of clouds. Changes in droplet size due to condensational growth were measured for realistic atmospheric radiant heat fluxes. Under the influence of radiative cooling, droplets were found to grow on the order of 50% in diameter—over 230% in volume or mass—in just 80 seconds.  During this time the droplet assembly’s temperature was found to drop from room temperature to within a few degrees of water’s freezing point. 

An analytical model of the radiative cooling and condensation process was developed. Laboratory measurements were used to develop and validate modeling assumptions by comparing the measurements with analytical predictions. New formulas were developed in the analysis including the time scale for the growth of condensing droplets exposed to radiative cooling, the time scale for droplet cooling, the relative augmentation ratio or effect of condensation on cooling time for condensing droplets over that for non-condensing or non-volatile droplets, the time scale for surrounding vapor to reach a quasi-steady relative humidity, and the corresponding value of this relative humidity. The analytical model successfully predicted all the time scales that could be measured experimentally. These included the droplet growth and cooling times, which were of the order of minutes. Detailed droplet size measurements and comparisons with predictions led to new findings about microphysical modeling practices of cloud radiative cooling and condensational droplet growth, including that radiation-induced condensational droplet growth needs to be modeled on a droplet-size-specific basis and not generically using an artificially elevated vapor relative humidity.  A new, simple analytical formula for quasi-steady vapor relative humidity was also found, which is a function of only the droplet size distribution, surface tension, and solute parameters, but not radiative transfer parameters. These findings will impact a fundamental problem in cloud microphysics: the problem of numerically modeling cloud droplet evolution in a complex, constantly changing fluid dynamic, thermodynamic, and radiative atmospheric environment. 

Broader Impacts

This study has had, and will have, broader impacts ranging from those on individual lives to society at-large. At the individual level this study most immediately affected the education and career of three graduate student, two of whose aspirations were/are to become educators. One has accomplished that goal and is continuing to conduct outreach and the other is well on her way to doing so as a continuing PhD student in Environmental Engineering. Locally, workshops were conducted for K-12 students on water properties, phase-change heat transfer, and global climate change in which inexpensive cloud chambers were built and thermodynamic properties measured. Educational aids were developed for outreach activities. This study also had a broader educational and curriculum impact by being incorporated into the graduate curriculum at the University of Illinois in the Thermal Radiation Heat Transfer class as a design project. At a larger, societal level this study will also have far-reaching impact. The findings obtained will allow a better fundamental understanding of cloud microphysics and may open a door to improved numerical weather prediction as well as global climate understanding. The ultimate broad impact of this project will be a more informed society with a more accurate understanding of the fundamental thermophysical properties and behavior of our industrial society’s primary thermal regulating fluid and Earth’s principal greenhouse substance and thermal-fluid driving force: water.
